In 2001 Charlie Burrell and Isabella Tree, the owners of Knepp Estate in the south of England, decided to transform their farm by "rewilding" it. When the pigs rootle in the mud with their snouts, it helps create habitats for other animals. Charlie Burrell/Knepp Wildland

As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

articles.name: The forgotten story of the US’ black cowboys
description: We and our partners use cookies to give you the best online experience, including to personalise advertising and content. Data about your interaction with this site and the ads shown to you may be shared with companies involved in the delivery and/or personalisation of ads on this site and elsewhere online.
Heathrow says it has been overtaken as Europe's busiest airport for the first time by Paris Charles de Gaulle because of a slump in demand for air travel.

"An astronaut, a pastor and an American football coach walk into the US Senate" sounds like the beginning of a joke, but that is what could happen when winners of the 2020 general election take their seats in Congress.
The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Tangier Island is slowly disappearing due to erosion and rising water levels, but this US community of fishermen is putting its faith in a sea wall - and President Trump - to protect their homes, jobs and way of life.
Turkey has vowed to take "legal, diplomatic actions" over a cartoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
A strike is under way in Poland by women opposed to a court ruling that introduced a near-total ban on abortion in the mainly Catholic country.
Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

"Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.
Henshaw came on in the first half of last weekend's 50-17 win over Italy after his Leinster team-mate Ringrose suffered a broken jaw
The US presidential election takes place 3 November. But it's possible the candidate with the most votes from the public won't be the winner.

Is China preparing to invade Taiwan? It's a question being discussed with feverish intensity on many China forums right now. And what should be one of the top geopolitical concerns for the incoming US president.

While one is comforted to have a constitutionalist conservative on the court, others fear she will vote to rescind essential rights for LGBT individuals, including marriage equality which passed the court in 2015.
Scientists add some bizarre things to vaccines, such as aluminium and extracts from shark livers. Many vaccines simply don’t work without them – but no one knows why.
By reimagining our relationship with time – and coming to terms with death – we can improve our existence, argues Roman Krznaric.
We've made some important changes to our Privacy and Cookies Policy and we want you to know what this means for you and your data.

At the time Teigen shared photos on Instagram of herself crying in hospital after learning that the baby boy she had been carrying was stillborn.
The stress levels rocketed for Ian Scott-Browne earlier this month, when one of his colleagues radioed him and told him to call the fire brigade.

When Kim Kyeong Yeon's 13-year-old daughter fell and injured herself on an escalator, she set in train events that years later might prevent millions of people around the world from contracting Covid-19.

As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

Credit reference agency Experian has been sharing the personal information of millions of people without consent and must stop, the UK's information commissioner has ruled.

The story of India's first "saviour sibling" has made national headlines. It has also raised questions about the ethics of using technology to create a child only to save or cure a sibling in a country with poor regulatory systems. The BBC's Geeta Pandey in Delhi reports.
Covid-19 upended our jobs. We've tried to adapt, but what about the long term? BBC Worklife asks dozens of experts to flag the biggest questions we should be asking in 2020 and beyond.
Millennials and Gen Z love caring for indoor plants. But why? Lindsay Baker speaks to the ‘plantfluencers’, and explores self-care – and the perennial appeal of the houseplant.
As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

description: We and our partners use cookies to give you the best online experience, including to personalise advertising and content. The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Tangier Island is slowly disappearing due to erosion and rising water levels, but this US community of fishermen is putting its faith in a sea wall - and President Trump - to protect their homes, jobs and way of life.
Turkey has vowed to take "legal, diplomatic actions" over a cartoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
A strike is under way in Poland by women opposed to a court ruling that introduced a near-total ban on abortion in the mainly Catholic country.
Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

"Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.

The US presidential election takes place 3 November. But it's possible the candidate with the most votes from the public won't be the winner.

Scientists add some bizarre things to vaccines, such as aluminium and extracts from shark livers. Many vaccines simply don’t work without them – but no one knows why.

"The world has had enough of the fake news spreaded [sic] daily" by the US president, a message on www.donaldjtrump.com briefly displayed.

Credit reference agency Experian has been sharing the personal information of millions of people without consent and must stop, the UK's information commissioner has ruled.

Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

Campaigners fear that the legal body designed to protect the environment on behalf of citizens is being undermined by the UK government.
The Chinese-owned firm has announced a tie-up with online retailer Shopify to help businesses create video ads to promote their products.
"The world has had enough of the fake news spreaded [sic] daily" by the US president, a message on www.donaldjtrump.com briefly displayed.
Europe's daily Covid deaths rose by nearly 40% compared with the previous week, the World Health Organization (WHO) has told the BBC.
Credit reference agency Experian has been sharing the personal information of millions of people without consent and must stop, the UK's information commissioner has ruled.

The story of India's first "saviour sibling" has made national headlines. It has also raised questions about the ethics of using technology to create a child only to save or cure a sibling in a country with poor regulatory systems. The BBC's Geeta Pandey in Delhi reports.
Covid-19 upended our jobs. We've tried to adapt, but what about the long term? BBC Worklife asks dozens of experts to flag the biggest questions we should be asking in 2020 and beyond.
Millennials and Gen Z love caring for indoor plants. But why? Lindsay Baker speaks to the ‘plantfluencers’, and explores self-care – and the perennial appeal of the houseplant.
As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

articles.name: 'Let me finish. Let me finish, OK?'
description: We and our partners use cookies to give you the best online experience, including to personalise advertising and content. Data about your interaction with this site and the ads shown to you may be shared with companies involved in the delivery and/or personalisation of ads on this site and elsewhere online.
Heathrow says it has been overtaken as Europe's busiest airport for the first time by Paris Charles de Gaulle because of a slump in demand for air travel.

"An astronaut, a pastor and an American football coach walk into the US Senate" sounds like the beginning of a joke, but that is what could happen when winners of the 2020 general election take their seats in Congress.
The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Tangier Island is slowly disappearing due to erosion and rising water levels, but this US community of fishermen is putting its faith in a sea wall - and President Trump - to protect their homes, jobs and way of life.
Turkey has vowed to take "legal, diplomatic actions" over a cartoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
A strike is under way in Poland by women opposed to a court ruling that introduced a near-total ban on abortion in the mainly Catholic country.
Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

"Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.
Henshaw came on in the first half of last weekend's 50-17 win over Italy after his Leinster team-mate Ringrose suffered a broken jaw
The US presidential election takes place 3 November. But it's possible the candidate with the most votes from the public won't be the winner.

Is China preparing to invade Taiwan? It's a question being discussed with feverish intensity on many China forums right now. And what should be one of the top geopolitical concerns for the incoming US president.

While one is comforted to have a constitutionalist conservative on the court, others fear she will vote to rescind essential rights for LGBT individuals, including marriage equality which passed the court in 2015.
Scientists add some bizarre things to vaccines, such as aluminium and extracts from shark livers. Many vaccines simply don’t work without them – but no one knows why.
By reimagining our relationship with time – and coming to terms with death – we can improve our existence, argues Roman Krznaric.
We've made some important changes to our Privacy and Cookies Policy and we want you to know what this means for you and your data.

When a leading medical expert urged people to prepare for a "digital Christmas" last week, the response was mixed. But amid the frustration and "mistletoe and Zoom" jokes, some people were already rearranging their plans.
At the time Teigen shared photos on Instagram of herself crying in hospital after learning that the baby boy she had been carrying was stillborn.
The stress levels rocketed for Ian Scott-Browne earlier this month, when one of his colleagues radioed him and told him to call the fire brigade.

When Kim Kyeong Yeon's 13-year-old daughter fell and injured herself on an escalator, she set in train events that years later might prevent millions of people around the world from contracting Covid-19.

Campaigners fear that the legal body designed to protect the environment on behalf of citizens is being undermined by the UK government.
The Chinese-owned firm has announced a tie-up with online retailer Shopify to help businesses create video ads to promote their products.
"The world has had enough of the fake news spreaded [sic] daily" by the US president, a message on www.donaldjtrump.com briefly displayed.
Europe's daily Covid deaths rose by nearly 40% compared with the previous week, the World Health Organization (WHO) has told the BBC.
Credit reference agency Experian has been sharing the personal information of millions of people without consent and must stop, the UK's information commissioner has ruled.

The story of India's first "saviour sibling" has made national headlines. It has also raised questions about the ethics of using technology to create a child only to save or cure a sibling in a country with poor regulatory systems. The BBC's Geeta Pandey in Delhi reports.
Covid-19 upended our jobs. We've tried to adapt, but what about the long term? BBC Worklife asks dozens of experts to flag the biggest questions we should be asking in 2020 and beyond.

As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

description: We and our partners use cookies to give you the best online experience, including to personalise advertising and content. Data about your interaction with this site and the ads shown to you may be shared with companies involved in the delivery and/or personalisation of ads on this site and elsewhere online.

The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Tangier Island is slowly disappearing due to erosion and rising water levels, but this US community of fishermen is putting its faith in a sea wall - and President Trump - to protect their homes, jobs and way of life.
Turkey has vowed to take "legal, diplomatic actions" over a cartoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
A strike is under way in Poland by women opposed to a court ruling that introduced a near-total ban on abortion in the mainly Catholic country.
Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

"Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.

Melbourne was at the heart of Australia's second wave of the coronavirus pandemic, and went into a second lockdown for nearly four months - the strictest the country had seen.
Comic Relief will stop sending celebrities to Africa after criticism that stars like Stacey Dooley were going to Africa as "white saviours".
Campaigners fear that the legal body designed to protect the environment on behalf of citizens is being undermined by the UK government.
The Chinese-owned firm has announced a tie-up with online retailer Shopify to help businesses create video ads to promote their products.
"The world has had enough of the fake news spreaded [sic] daily" by the US president, a message on www.donaldjtrump.com briefly displayed.
Europe's daily Covid deaths rose by nearly 40% compared with the previous week, the World Health Organization (WHO) has told the BBC.
Credit reference agency Experian has been sharing the personal information of millions of people without consent and must stop, the UK's information commissioner has ruled.

The story of India's first "saviour sibling" has made national headlines. It has also raised questions about the ethics of using technology to create a child only to save or cure a sibling in a country with poor regulatory systems. The BBC's Geeta Pandey in Delhi reports.
Covid-19 upended our jobs. We've tried to adapt, but what about the long term? BBC Worklife asks dozens of experts to flag the biggest questions we should be asking in 2020 and beyond.
Millennials and Gen Z love caring for indoor plants. But why? Lindsay Baker speaks to the ‘plantfluencers’, and explores self-care – and the perennial appeal of the houseplant.
As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

description: We and our partners use cookies to give you the best online experience, including to personalise advertising and content. The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Tangier Island is slowly disappearing due to erosion and rising water levels, but this US community of fishermen is putting its faith in a sea wall - and President Trump - to protect their homes, jobs and way of life.
Turkey has vowed to take "legal, diplomatic actions" over a cartoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
A strike is under way in Poland by women opposed to a court ruling that introduced a near-total ban on abortion in the mainly Catholic country.
Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

"Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.

John Bolton, President Donald Trump's former National Security Adviser, had a heated exchange with Newsnight's Emily Maitlis.
With a week to go until the US presidential election, more than 60 million Americans have already taken advantage of early voting, smashing all records.
Melbourne was at the heart of Australia's second wave of the coronavirus pandemic, and went into a second lockdown for nearly four months - the strictest the country had seen.
Comic Relief will stop sending celebrities to Africa after criticism that stars like Stacey Dooley were going to Africa as "white saviours".
Campaigners fear that the legal body designed to protect the environment on behalf of citizens is being undermined by the UK government.
The Chinese-owned firm has announced a tie-up with online retailer Shopify to help businesses create video ads to promote their products.
"The world has had enough of the fake news spreaded [sic] daily" by the US president, a message on www.donaldjtrump.com briefly displayed.
Europe's daily Covid deaths rose by nearly 40% compared with the previous week, the World Health Organization (WHO) has told the BBC.
Credit reference agency Experian has been sharing the personal information of millions of people without consent and must stop, the UK's information commissioner has ruled.

The story of India's first "saviour sibling" has made national headlines. It has also raised questions about the ethics of using technology to create a child only to save or cure a sibling in a country with poor regulatory systems. The BBC's Geeta Pandey in Delhi reports.
Covid-19 upended our jobs. We've tried to adapt, but what about the long term? BBC Worklife asks dozens of experts to flag the biggest questions we should be asking in 2020 and beyond.
Millennials and Gen Z love caring for indoor plants. But why? Lindsay Baker speaks to the ‘plantfluencers’, and explores self-care – and the perennial appeal of the houseplant.
As the clocks go back this autumn, the horological conservator at Windsor Castle will be busy changing more than 400 clocks from the Royal Collection Trust.
President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden went head-to-head in their final debate of the election campaign at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee.
A day earlier in the Ivory Coast, a supporter of the ruling party wears a hat which reads "live together RHDP". The country is heading into a presidential election at the end of the month.
The company behind the new rapid rail connection between London and the north of England is cutting down trees in the course of the construction.
Protests over a now-disbanded police unit, the Special Anti-Robbery Squad (Sars), have been taking place in Nigeria for two weeks.

description: We and our partners use cookies to give you the best online experience, including to personalise advertising and content. Data about your interaction with this site and the ads shown to you may be shared with companies involved in the delivery and/or personalisation of ads on this site and elsewhere online.
Heathrow says it has been overtaken as Europe's busiest airport for the first time by Paris Charles de Gaulle because of a slump in demand for air travel.

"An astronaut, a pastor and an American football coach walk into the US Senate" sounds like the beginning of a joke, but that is what could happen when winners of the 2020 general election take their seats in Congress.
The pandemic quashed the experience of learning in a traditional office. Can younger workers grow in the same way while working at their kitchen tables?

On a chilly afternoon in Mesquite, Texas, Cleo Hearn sat in the bleachers at a rodeo competition as hundreds of young cowboys trotted around the dirt in colourful Western yoke shirts. With his cloud of white hair poking out from under a cream-coloured cowboy hat, the 80-year-old analysed the wranglers’ techniques and explained what made each cowboy successful or fumbling as they tried to lasso the feisty yearling cattle.

Tangier Island is slowly disappearing due to erosion and rising water levels, but this US community of fishermen is putting its faith in a sea wall - and President Trump - to protect their homes, jobs and way of life.
Turkey has vowed to take "legal, diplomatic actions" over a cartoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
A strike is under way in Poland by women opposed to a court ruling that introduced a near-total ban on abortion in the mainly Catholic country.
Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators, and say they are "bemused" by the ongoing ban on fans at stadiums.

"Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.

The US presidential election takes place 3 November. But it's possible the candidate with the most votes from the public won't be the winner.

Is China preparing to invade Taiwan? It's a question being discussed with feverish intensity on many China forums right now. And what should be one of the top geopolitical concerns for the incoming US president.

Scientists add some bizarre things to vaccines, such as aluminium and extracts from shark livers. Many vaccines simply don’t work without them – but no one knows why.
By reimagining our relationship with time – and coming to terms with death – we can improve our existence, argues Roman Krznaric.
